comments:
LGST210, or “Corporate Responsibilities and Ethics,” is concerned with real-life cases, with the various theories and modes of thought that can be applied as tools to help resolve ethical problems. The goal of this course is to build a framework to better identify, analyze and resolve the wide range of ethical issues that arise in business. 

The majority of students found that they learned a great deal from this course. Many students mentioned finding the lectures “not only interesting but intellectually stimulating and challenging.” Students also reported enjoying the trips organized by the professor.

Students praised Professor Laufer, commenting that he “truly cares about his students and takes the time to stimulate interest in the subject matter.” Overall, most found Professor Laufer to be approachable and vested in the interest of the students’ learning.

The grade for the course is broken up into a midterm exam, final exam, a short paper, and class participation. There are no major prerequisites listed for this course.

This course explores business responsibility from rival theoretical and managerial perspectives. Its focus includes theories of ethics and their application to case studies in business. Topics include moral issues in advertising and sales; hiring and promotion; financial management; corporate pollution; product safety; and decision-making across borders and cultures.

For the most part students seemed to enjoy this “interesting” class that was “very discussion based.” While many students enjoyed the class discussions, they were often referred to as, “not very focused” and could sometimes “go far off on a tangent.” The debates were “enjoyable and interesting to take part in,” but the reading and structured lectures can be “boring.”

While students differed greatly in their opinions of the class, Professor Hussain as a lecturer was praised greatly. He is described as “very eloquent and clear” and his lectures “get everyone involved.” Professor Hussain allows the class to be guided by discussion and debate, rather than the course materials and syllabus. He teaches the material in a way that “makes it relatable and applicable to the workplace.”

Students were very clear that this class is discussion and debate based, and in order to do well, you must participate a lot. They did wish, however, that there were a greater correlation between effort and grades, as the readings weren’t necessary to get a decent grade. This course was taken by both freshmen and upperclassmen.
